articles.headline: With Uber and Lyft Nearby, Rental Cars May Be Ripe for a Comeuppance
articles.snippet: Lagging customer service and a host of inconveniences give travelers a long list of reasons to avoid car rental companies altogether.
articles.abstract: Lagging customer service and a host of inconveniences give travelers a long list of reasons to avoid car rental companies altogether.
articles.lead_paragraph: The day before Election Day, even the most frequent of travelers may have missed the bad news about Hertz. After a disappointing earnings release, its stock fell by 23 percent.

articles.headline: When a Business Faltered, Small Investors Stood Their Ground
articles.snippet: A case involving Breitburn Energy Partners could offer a lesson for individual investors who are being run over by the company.
articles.abstract: A case involving Breitburn Energy Partners could offer a lesson for individual investors who are being run over by the company.
articles.lead_paragraph: Individual investors can feel powerless when their stock investments go awry. But sometimes it pays to fight back.

articles.headline: Russian Hackers Acted to Aid Trump in Election, U.S. Says
articles.snippet: Officials have “high confidence” in their conclusion partly because of another finding: Russia hacked Republican Party computers but did not release the information.
articles.abstract: Officials have “high confidence” in their conclusion partly because of another finding: Russia hacked Republican Party computers but did not release the information.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American intelligence agencies have concluded with “high confidence” that Russia acted covertly in the latter stages of the presidential campaign to harm Hillary Clinton’s chances and promote Donald J. Trump, according to senior administration officials.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Scott Shane

articles.headline: Telling Their Life Stories, Older Adults Find Peace in Looking Back
articles.snippet: Some take life-story writing classes, while others hire “personal historians” to record oral histories or to produce videos that combine interviews, home movies and family photos.
articles.abstract: Some take life-story writing classes, while others hire “personal historians” to record oral histories or to produce videos that combine interviews, home movies and family photos.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISABELLA S. BICK’S parents, both Jewish physicians, never talked about the past after the family moved from Fascist Italy to the United States in 1939. She was 8 at the time and quickly learned it was best to keep her feelings of loss and loneliness to herself.

articles.headline: Jurors Hear Dylann Roof Explain Shooting in Video: ‘I Had to Do It’
articles.snippet: On the third day of Mr. Roof’s federal death penalty trial, jurors heard him elaborate on the massacre at a prominent black church in Charleston, S.C., and his motives.
articles.abstract: On the third day of Mr. Roof’s federal death penalty trial, jurors heard him elaborate on the massacre at a prominent black church in Charleston, S.C., and his motives.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — Shortly after being arrested and about 17 hours after he shot up the fellowship hall at Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church, Dylann S. Roof sat at an oval conference table with two F.B.I. agents and confessed — calmly, clinically, occasionally chortling — to killing nine people who he acknowledged could not have been more innocent.
articles.byline: By Kevin Sack and Alan Blinder

articles.headline: Calls Aren’t Allowed on Planes, but Regulators Consider a Warning Anyway
articles.snippet: The Transportation Department has proposed that passengers be warned if an airline allows voice calls over in-flight Wi-Fi, which most carriers now forbid.
articles.abstract: The Transportation Department has proposed that passengers be warned if an airline allows voice calls over in-flight Wi-Fi, which most carriers now forbid.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over time, airline passengers have been deprived of comfortable seats, passable food, space for some carry-on luggage, leg room, head room, arm room and any other amenities that may separate humans from cattle.

articles.headline: Trump’s Honeymoon Begins: Confidence in the Economy Is Booming
articles.snippet: Much of the swelling confidence may come from one political party, but consumers, business leaders and Wall Street show a lot of excitement.
articles.abstract: Much of the swelling confidence may come from one political party, but consumers, business leaders and Wall Street show a lot of excitement.
articles.lead_paragraph: Consumers say they are more confident. Business leaders, once wary, are now expressing excitement that one of their own is headed toward the White House. And Wall Street is bordering on the ecstatic.
articles.byline: By Patricia Cohen and Landon Thomas Jr

articles.headline: Accusations of Fraud at Wells Fargo Spread to Sham Insurance Policies
articles.snippet: Three whistle-blowers have filed a wrongful termination suit against the insurer Prudential, saying they were fired for trying to draw attention to dishonest conduct at Wells Fargo.
articles.abstract: Three whistle-blowers have filed a wrongful termination suit against the insurer Prudential, saying they were fired for trying to draw attention to dishonest conduct at Wells Fargo.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Wells Fargo admitted a few months ago that thousands of its employees had created as many as two million unauthorized accounts for its customers, alarm bells went off at Prudential, one of the nation’s biggest insurance firms.
articles.byline: By Stacy Cowley and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: An ‘Apprentice’ Role for Trump Opens Door Wide for Questions
articles.snippet: Aides to the president-elect defended his right to profit from the NBC reality show, even as ally Newt Gingrich called the president-elect’s involvement “weird.”
articles.abstract: Aides to the president-elect defended his right to profit from the NBC reality show, even as ally Newt Gingrich called the president-elect’s involvement “weird.”
articles.lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump is entering office with financial entanglements that are exotic and far-flung: a condominium project in Manila, a luxury furniture maker in Istanbul, golf courses in Scotland and Ireland, and a hotel in Azerbaijan.

articles.headline: Wall Street Is Europe’s Landlord. And Tenants Are Fighting Back.
articles.snippet: Huge profits and dubious tax strategies have made investment firms in America the object of frustration and anger, as many Europeans face eviction and fear becoming homeless.
articles.abstract: Huge profits and dubious tax strategies have made investment firms in America the object of frustration and anger, as many Europeans face eviction and fear becoming homeless.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — The Tobun family never missed a rental payment on their modest brick rowhouse in eight years. But in February, the couple, who have two young children, received a letter warning that they would have to leave their home when the lease expired. Forty of their neighbors got the same notice.

articles.headline: How the Twinkie Made the Superrich Even Richer
articles.snippet: Behind the financial maneuvering at Hostess, an investigation by The New York Times found a blueprint for how private equity executives have amassed some of the greatest fortunes of the modern era.
articles.abstract: Behind the financial maneuvering at Hostess, an investigation by The New York Times found a blueprint for how private equity executives have amassed some of the greatest fortunes of the modern era.
articles.lead_paragraph: As fans gathered on Rockefeller Plaza in Manhattan, Al Roker pulled up in a big red delivery truck, ready to give America what it wanted: Twinkies.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Trump, Mocking Claim That Russia Hacked Election, at Odds with G.O.P.
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump’s team lashed out at intelligence agencies after The Washington Post reported that the C.I.A. believed that Russia had intervened to undercut Hillary Clinton.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump’s team lashed out at intelligence agencies after The Washington Post reported that the C.I.A. believed that Russia had intervened to undercut Hillary Clinton.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An extraordinary breach has emerged between President-elect Donald J. Trump and the national security establishment, with Mr. Trump mocking American intelligence assessments that Russia interfered in the election on his behalf, and top Republicans vowing investigations into Kremlin activities.

articles.headline: An Alt-Right Makeover Shrouds the Swastikas
articles.snippet: A movement of many factions is trying to change its image now that its profile has risen, but its message — one of racial separation and supremacy — is unchanged.
articles.abstract: A movement of many factions is trying to change its image now that its profile has risen, but its message — one of racial separation and supremacy — is unchanged.
articles.lead_paragraph: A small but determined political organization in Detroit began to worry that its official symbol was a bit off-putting. With the group’s central philosophy suddenly finding traction in the daily discourse, appearances mattered.
articles.byline: By Serge F. Kovaleski, Julie Turkewitz, Joseph Goldstein and Dan Barry

articles.headline: Rex Tillerson, Exxon Chief, Is Expected to Be Pick for Secretary of State
articles.snippet: Mr. Tillerson’s extensive deal-making around the world has engendered close ties with a number of world leaders, including President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
articles.abstract: Mr. Tillerson’s extensive deal-making around the world has engendered close ties with a number of world leaders, including President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Rex W. Tillerson, the chief executive of Exxon Mobil, whose extensive deal-making for the energy giant has plunged him into global politics from Yemen to Russia, is expected to be offered the secretary of state post this weekend by President-elect Donald J. Trump, according to two people close to Mr. Trump’s transition team.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Maggie Haberman and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Small Investors Join China’s Tycoons in Sending Money Abroad
articles.snippet: Middle-class Chinese are using new technology to move their wealth out of the country and into American investments, from San Francisco to New York.
articles.abstract: Middle-class Chinese are using new technology to move their wealth out of the country and into American investments, from San Francisco to New York.
articles.lead_paragraph: Adam Dahill saw promise in the three-story brownstone on a quiet Bedford-Stuyvesant street, despite its weather-beaten facade, crumbling front steps and broken windows. But he needed nearly $1.3 million to buy it and turn it into the sort of Brooklyn dream home for which the city’s lawyers and bankers pay big money.
articles.byline: By Emily Feng and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: Designing a Safer Battery for Smartphones (That Won’t Catch Fire)
articles.snippet: A Massachusetts start-up is part of a new wave of efforts in the United States, Europe and Asia to improve battery technologies as consumers demand more from phones and cars.
articles.abstract: A Massachusetts start-up is part of a new wave of efforts in the United States, Europe and Asia to improve battery technologies as consumers demand more from phones and cars.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Mike Zimmerman likes to shock his guests by using a hammer to drive a nail through a solid polymer lithium metal battery.

articles.headline: Google Effect Rubs Off on Schools in One Rural Oklahoma Town
articles.snippet: A $2.5 billion data center transforms the learning experiences of a rural community’s students in a state where schools are struggling.
articles.abstract: A $2.5 billion data center transforms the learning experiences of a rural community’s students in a state where schools are struggling.
articles.lead_paragraph: PRYOR, Okla. — Students at Pryor High School study robotics. Elementary schools have basic computer programming classes using free laptops, online collaboration software and Wi-Fi spread across this small town in Oklahoma’s Green Country.

articles.headline: In Trump Era, Uncompromising TV News Should Be the Norm, Not the Exception
articles.snippet: A CNN interview with Vice President-elect Mike Pence was held up as a shining example of stand-up journalism. But such moments now seem so rare.
articles.abstract: A CNN interview with Vice President-elect Mike Pence was held up as a shining example of stand-up journalism. But such moments now seem so rare.
articles.lead_paragraph: Too often television news, especially on cable, serves as a megaphone for politicians who use it to forward lies and propaganda while so effortlessly ignoring questions they’re supposedly there to answer.

articles.headline: C.I.A. Judgment on Russia Built on Swell of Evidence
articles.snippet: The conclusion that Russia intervened in the election to help Donald J. Trump was based on what many believe is overwhelming circumstantial evidence, which is often the most intelligence analysts have at their disposal.
articles.abstract: The conclusion that Russia intervened in the election to help Donald J. Trump was based on what many believe is overwhelming circumstantial evidence, which is often the most intelligence analysts have at their disposal.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American spy and law enforcement agencies were united in the belief, in the weeks before the presidential election, that the Russian government had deployed computer hackers to sow chaos during the campaign. But they had conflicting views about the specific goals of the subterfuge.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Eric Lichtblau

articles.headline: Boeing Speaks in Trump Terms on Iran Deal: It’s About Jobs
articles.snippet: With a $16.6 billion sale of planes to Iran, Boeing said the agreement would “support tens of thousands of U.S. jobs,” perhaps speaking toward President-elect Donald J. Trump.
articles.abstract: With a $16.6 billion sale of planes to Iran, Boeing said the agreement would “support tens of thousands of U.S. jobs,” perhaps speaking toward President-elect Donald J. Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: Boeing announced a $16.6 billion deal on Sunday to sell planes to Iran, which for decades had been economically blacklisted by the United States. The company instead chose to emphasize how many jobs the sale would support.

articles.headline: Abortion Foes, Emboldened by Trump, Promise ‘Onslaught’ of Tough Restrictions
articles.snippet: Legalized abortion faces its greatest threat in decades, people on both sides of the issue say, and that includes the possibility that Roe v. Wade will be overturned.
articles.abstract: Legalized abortion faces its greatest threat in decades, people on both sides of the issue say, and that includes the possibility that Roe v. Wade will be overturned.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Christina Hagan, the youngest woman in the Ohio Legislature, received a surprise last week. The toughest piece of abortion legislation in the country — a bill she had championed for years — suddenly passed.
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: For Women Under ISIS, a Tyranny of Dress Code and Punishment
articles.snippet: Escapees from the Iraqi city of Mosul describe the Islamic State’s extreme dress code, which made showing so much as an eyebrow an offense punishable by the whip.
articles.abstract: Escapees from the Iraqi city of Mosul describe the Islamic State’s extreme dress code, which made showing so much as an eyebrow an offense punishable by the whip.
articles.lead_paragraph: KHAZER CAMP, Iraq — By the time the jihadists had finished, not even a woman’s eyes were legal. Showing them was a punishable offense.

articles.headline: After a Crime, the Price of a Second Chance
articles.snippet: A program called diversion was supposed to spare low-level offenders the ruinous consequences of a criminal record. Then money got in the way.
articles.abstract: A program called diversion was supposed to spare low-level offenders the ruinous consequences of a criminal record. Then money got in the way.
articles.lead_paragraph: During the tough financial times of 2011, Marcy Willis, a single mother who raised five children in Atlanta, used her credit card to rent a car for an acquaintance in exchange for cash. But the man — and the car — disappeared, she said. Four months later, when Ms. Willis finally recovered the car and returned it, she was charged with felony theft.
articles.byline: By Shaila Dewan and Andrew W. Lehren

articles.headline: Christine Lagarde on Trial in France, Overshadowing I.M.F. Role
articles.snippet: The case caps a long-running legal drama that has captivated the public and exposed ties between powerful politicians and the wealthy.
articles.abstract: The case caps a long-running legal drama that has captivated the public and exposed ties between powerful politicians and the wealthy.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Christine Lagarde, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, went on trial in Paris on Monday, facing criminal charges that when she was France’s finance minister, her negligence resulted in the misuse of hundreds of millions of euros in public money.

articles.headline: Redstones Reverse Course and Put a Stop to Viacom-CBS Merger
articles.snippet: Sumner Redstone and his daughter, Shari, the owner of two companies, say they should focus on “their independent paths forward.”
articles.abstract: Sumner Redstone and his daughter, Shari, the owner of two companies, say they should focus on “their independent paths forward.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Viacom is going it alone. The troubled media company named Robert M. Bakish as its new chief executive on Monday just hours after it received marching orders to stop exploring a combination with CBS.
